title: Psalms Chapter 38 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 38 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 38 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 38.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 38?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:1 identifies this Psalm as a Psalm of David.

questions.question: What does David ask the LORD not to do in His wrath?
questions.correctAnswer: Rebuke him
questions.explanation: In Psalms 38:1, David asks the LORD not to rebuke him in His wrath.

questions.question: According to Psalms 38:2, what sticks fast in David?
questions.correctAnswer: Arrows
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:2 states that the LORD's arrows stick fast in David.

questions.question: What is the reason given for there being no rest in David's bones?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of his sin
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:3 explains there is no rest in David's bones because of his sin.

questions.question: According to Psalms 38:4, how does David describe his iniquities?
questions.correctAnswer: As a heavy burden
questions.explanation: David describes his iniquities as a heavy burden too heavy for him in Psalms 38:4.

questions.question: What condition does David say his wounds have because of his foolishness?
questions.correctAnswer: They stink and are corrupt
questions.explanation: In Psalms 38:5, David states his wounds stink and are corrupt due to his foolishness.

questions.question: How does David describe his physical state in Psalms 38:7?
options: Loins filled with a loathsome disease
questions.correctAnswer: Loins filled with a loathsome disease
questions.explanation: David says his loins are filled with a loathsome disease and there is no soundness in his flesh in Psalms 38:7.

questions.question: What has gone from David's eyes according to Psalms 38:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The light
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:10 states that the light of David's eyes is gone from him.

questions.question: Who stands aloof from David's sore as mentioned in Psalms 38:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Lovers and friends
questions.explanation: According to Psalms 38:11, David's lovers and friends stand aloof from his sore.

questions.question: What do those who seek David's life do, according to Psalms 38:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Lay snares for him
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:12 says those who seek David's life lay snares for him.

questions.question: True or False: David compares himself to a deaf and dumb man who does not open his mouth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In Psalms 38:13, David compares himself to a deaf man who hears not and a dumb man who opens not his mouth.

questions.question: True or False: David expresses hope only in men and not in the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:15 shows David hopes in the LORD and expects Him to hear.

questions.question: True or False: David asks the LORD to be far from him in his time of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: In Psalms 38:21, David asks the LORD not to forsake him and not to be far from him.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 38:22: 'Make haste to help me, O Lord my ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:22 says, 'Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 38:18, what does David declare and feel sorry for?
questions.correctAnswer: His iniquity and sin
questions.explanation: David declares his iniquity and is sorry for his sin in Psalms 38:18.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 38 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 38 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed by their own sins and feels burdened. Based on Psalms 38, what biblical truth would you share about dealing with guilt?
options: Iniquities can feel like a heavy burden, but God’s mercy can relieve us.
Sin should be ignored because it will go away on its own.
We must bear the burden of sin without seeking God’s help.
God’s anger is permanent and there is no relief from it.
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquities can feel like a heavy burden, but God’s mercy can relieve us.
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:4 describes iniquities as a heavy burden, while the overall psalm shows a plea for God's help and mercy (verses 1, 15, 21). This teaches that while sin burdens us, trusting God brings relief.

questions.question: How does Psalms 38 teach us about humility when facing personal trials?
options: We should openly declare our sins and be sorry for them.
We must hide our faults from others to appear strong.
We should blame others for our troubles.
We should respond to trials with anger and pride.
questions.correctAnswer: We should openly declare our sins and be sorry for them.
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:18 emphasizes declaring iniquity and being sorry for sin, teaching humble confession and repentance as part of godly perseverance.

questions.question: A believer feels abandoned by friends during a difficult time. According to Psalms 38, what encouragement can you offer about God’s presence?
options: God is near and will not forsake you even if others stand afar off.
Friends are more reliable than God in times of trouble.
Isolation is a sign that God has turned away from you.
You should rely only on yourself when friends leave.
questions.correctAnswer: God is near and will not forsake you even if others stand afar off.
questions.explanation: Verses 11 and 21 highlight that while friends may stand aloof, the psalmist pleads with God not to forsake him, affirming God’s faithful presence in trials.

questions.question: Which verse in Psalms 38 teaches the importance of prayer and trusting God as our salvation?
options: Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation.
My wounds stink and are corrupt because of my foolishness.
My loins are filled with a loathsome disease.
They that seek my hurt speak mischievous things.
questions.correctAnswer: Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation.
questions.explanation: Verse 22 is a direct call to God for help, showing trust and urgency in prayer toward God as Savior.

questions.question: How does Psalms 38 challenge believers to respond to enemies who act unjustly?
options: Continue to do good even when evil is returned.
Retaliate with equal evil to defend yourself.
Avoid all contact with enemies at all costs.
Ignore the situation and focus on personal gain.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to do good even when evil is returned.
questions.explanation: Verse 20 notes the psalmist’s adversaries render evil for good, yet he follows what is good, teaching integrity and perseverance in righteousness.

questions.question: What does Psalms 38 reveal about the condition of the psalmist’s body and spirit during trials?
options: The psalmist feels weak, broken, and troubled in both body and heart.
The psalmist experiences physical strength despite spiritual weakness.
The psalmist is joyful and peaceful throughout the trial.
The psalmist ignores bodily pain and focuses only on the spirit.
questions.correctAnswer: The psalmist feels weak, broken, and troubled in both body and heart.
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 describe the psalmist as bowed down, troubled, feeble, and sore broken, showing the deep impact of sin and suffering.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 38, the psalmist’s prayers and groaning are hidden from the Lord.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:9 states that the psalmist’s desire and groaning are not hidden from God, showing God’s intimate knowledge of our prayers.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist in Psalms 38 feels confident that God will hear him and provide help.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 15 and 22 express hope and confidence that God will hear and hasten to help the psalmist in his distress.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "For mine iniquities are gone over mine _______, as a heavy burden they are too heavy for me."
questions.correctAnswer: head
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:4 uses 'head' to depict how sins overwhelm the psalmist like a heavy burden, showing the weight of guilt.

questions.question: How does Psalms 38 encourage believers to respond when friends and family distance themselves in times of trouble?
options: Continue seeking God’s help and trust in His presence.
Become angry and cut off all relationships.
Stop praying since God has abandoned you too.
Focus only on self-reliance without others.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue seeking God’s help and trust in His presence.
questions.explanation: Verses 11 and 21 show friends standing aloof but the psalmist still calls on God not to forsake him, encouraging reliance on God above people.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about how he responds to those who seek to harm him?
options: He remains silent like a deaf and dumb man.
questions.correctAnswer: He remains silent like a deaf and dumb man.
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 14 describe the psalmist as hearing not and opening not his mouth, showing a posture of silent endurance and restraint.

questions.question: According to Psalms 38, what should a believer do when feeling physically and spiritually weak?
options: Pour out their heart to the Lord and trust Him to hear.
Hide their weakness from others and appear strong.
Abandon prayer and rely solely on human help.
Give up hope and accept defeat.
questions.correctAnswer: Pour out their heart to the Lord and trust Him to hear.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 reveal the psalmist’s panting heart and fading strength but also that all desires and groaning are before God, encouraging prayer and trust.

questions.question: How does Psalms 38 illustrate the importance of honesty in our relationship with God?
options: By openly confessing sins and expressing sorrow.
By pretending to be without fault.
By blaming others for our problems.
By avoiding God when feeling guilty.
questions.correctAnswer: By openly confessing sins and expressing sorrow.
questions.explanation: Verse 18 highlights declaring iniquity and being sorry for sin, showing the biblical value of honesty and repentance before God.

questions.question: In Psalms 38, what does the psalmist ask God to do quickly?
options: Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation.
Send angels to fight my enemies.
Bring riches and honor to me.
questions.correctAnswer: Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation.
questions.explanation: Verse 22 is a plea for God’s swift assistance, teaching believers to earnestly seek God’s help in times of need.

questions.question: What does Psalms 38 teach about the attitude we should have when facing deception and malicious talk?
options: Trust God and remain silent rather than retaliate.
Engage in similar deceit to defend yourself.
Spread rumors about those who harm you.
Ignore God and rely on personal wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God and remain silent rather than retaliate.
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 describe enemies plotting deceit and the psalmist responding as a deaf and dumb man, implying trust in God over retaliation.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 38 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 38.

questions.question: In Psalms 38, David describes his sin as a burden too heavy to bear. Which of the following best represents this imagery?
options: His iniquities are gone over his head
His wounds stink and are corrupt
He roars by reason of the disquietness of his heart
His loins are filled with a loathsome disease
questions.correctAnswer: His iniquities are gone over his head
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:4 uses the metaphor of iniquities going over his head as a heavy burden, emphasizing the weight of sin on David.

questions.question: The description of 'arrows sticking fast' and God's hand pressing sore in Psalms 38:2 is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: In Psalms 38:2, arrows and pressing hand symbolize God's judgment and affliction, representing a metaphor for suffering.

questions.question: Psalm 38 expresses a deep sense of physical and spiritual suffering. Which other biblical book similarly explores the theme of suffering and divine discipline?
questions.correctAnswer: Job
questions.explanation: Like Psalms 38, Job extensively explores suffering and God's discipline, aligning with the themes of agony and divine testing.

questions.question: According to Psalms 38:11, what is the response of David's friends and kinsmen during his affliction?
options: They stand aloof and afar off
They gather around to comfort him
They confront him about his sins
questions.correctAnswer: They stand aloof and afar off
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:11 states that David's friends and kinsmen keep their distance, indicating social isolation during his suffering.

questions.question: The phrase 'I am as a deaf man, I heard not' in Psalms 38:13 is an example of what type of biblical imagery?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile expressing silence and passivity
questions.explanation: David likens himself to a deaf man who does not hear and a dumb man who does not speak, emphasizing his silent endurance (Psalms 38:13).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes David’s plea in Psalms 38:21-22 for God not to forsake him and to hasten salvation?
questions.correctAnswer: Hebrews 13:5-6
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:5-6 assures believers God will never leave nor forsake them, echoing the trust and plea found in Psalms 38:21-22.

questions.question: In Psalms 38:5, David’s wounds are described as 'stinking and corrupt' due to what cause?
questions.correctAnswer: His foolishness
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:5 explicitly attributes the corruption of wounds to David’s foolishness, linking sin with physical and spiritual decay.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word conceptually underpins the idea of 'chasten' or 'rebuke' found in Psalms 38:1 and is commonly associated with divine discipline?
questions.correctAnswer: Yasar
questions.explanation: 'Yasar' (to instruct, discipline) is the Hebrew root often translated as chasten or rebuke, reflecting God's corrective discipline in Psalms 38:1.

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 38, David’s enemies are described as weak and few in number.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:19 describes David’s enemies as lively, strong, and multiplied, indicating numerous and powerful adversaries.

questions.question: The repeated expressions of bodily weakness such as 'no soundness in my flesh' and 'feeble and sore broken' in Psalms 38 serve to communicate what theological theme?
options: The impact of sin on the whole person
questions.correctAnswer: The impact of sin on the whole person
questions.explanation: Verses like Psalms 38:3 and 38:8 emphasize physical and spiritual frailty caused by sin, showing its comprehensive burden.

questions.question: In Psalms 38:12, what tactics do David’s enemies use against him?
options: They lay snares and imagine deceits
They openly confront him in battle
questions.correctAnswer: They lay snares and imagine deceits
questions.explanation: Psalms 38:12 states enemies lay snares and speak mischievous things, revealing covert and malicious opposition.

questions.question: How does the structure of Psalms 38 reflect a chiastic pattern emphasizing David’s despair and hope?
options: Despair in the beginning and end, hope centered in God
Hope in the beginning and end, despair centered in enemies
Alternating verses of hope and despair
questions.correctAnswer: Despair in the beginning and end, hope centered in God
questions.explanation: Psalms 38 opens with lament over sin and closes with hope in the Lord (Psalms 38:1, 38:15, 38:21-22), forming a chiastic structure of despair and trust.

questions.question: The phrase 'My heart panteth, my strength faileth me' in Psalms 38:10 can be thematically linked to which Old Testament figure who also expressed physical and emotional exhaustion before God?
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah
questions.explanation: Elijah expressed similar exhaustion and despair (1 Kings 19:4), paralleling David’s lament about strength failing in Psalms 38:10.

questions.question: In Psalms 38:18, David states his intention to declare his iniquity and be sorry for his sin. Which New Testament teaching aligns with this confession and repentance?
questions.correctAnswer: 1 John 1:9 – confession and forgiveness
questions.explanation: 1 John 1:9 emphasizes confessing sins to receive forgiveness, aligning with David’s resolve in Psalms 38:18 to confess and repent.

questions.question: What does the 'loathsome disease' mentioned in Psalms 38:7 metaphorically represent in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: The corruption and guilt of sin
questions.correctAnswer: The corruption and guilt of sin
questions.explanation: In Psalms 38:7, the loathsome disease symbolizes the spiritual and moral corruption caused by sin, a common metaphor in ancient Near Eastern texts.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 38 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 38 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is David's primary request to the LORD in Psalms 38:1?
options: Do not rebuke me in Your wrath
Remove my enemies from before me
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rebuke me in Your wrath
questions.explanation: David asks God not to rebuke him in wrath or chasten him in hot displeasure, revealing his awareness of God's righteous anger and his plea for mercy (Psalms 38:1). This aligns with God's character as merciful in Exodus 34:6-7, and David's recognition of God's discipline is echoed in Hebrews 12:6.

questions.question: According to Psalms 38:4, how does David describe the burden of his sins?
options: Too heavy and gone over his head
questions.correctAnswer: Too heavy and gone over his head
questions.explanation: David describes his iniquities as overwhelming, too heavy for him, symbolizing the crushing weight of sin (Psalms 38:4). This concept is consistent with Isaiah 53:6 which describes mankind’s burden of sin, and Psalm 32:3-4 which speaks of the physical and emotional effects of unconfessed sin.

questions.question: What physical condition does David use to describe his suffering in Psalms 38:7?
options: Loins filled with a loathsome disease
questions.correctAnswer: Loins filled with a loathsome disease
questions.explanation: David uses the metaphor of a loathsome disease in his loins to express deep physical and spiritual distress (Psalms 38:7). This imagery of physical suffering due to sin is echoed in Jeremiah 30:12-15 and also aligns with the New Testament teaching of sin causing spiritual death (Romans 6:23).

questions.question: In Psalms 38:9, what does David say about his desires and groaning before the LORD?
options: They are all before God and not hidden
They are only for earthly things
questions.correctAnswer: They are all before God and not hidden
questions.explanation: David acknowledges that all his desires and groanings are known and seen by God, illustrating God’s omniscience and compassion (Psalms 38:9). This is consistent with 1 Peter 5:7 where believers cast their cares on God, and Psalm 34:15 which states that the LORD hears the cries of the righteous.

questions.question: What does David say about the response of his lovers, friends, and kinsmen in Psalms 38:11?
options: They stand aloof and afar off from his sorrow
They comfort him in his distress
questions.correctAnswer: They stand aloof and afar off from his sorrow
questions.explanation: David laments that even his close relationships fail him in times of suffering, emphasizing human frailty and loneliness in sin's consequences (Psalms 38:11). This experience parallels Job 19:13-19 and Jesus’ own experience of abandonment (Mark 14:50).

questions.question: What tactic do David's enemies use against him according to Psalms 38:12?
options: They lay snares and speak mischievous things
questions.correctAnswer: They lay snares and speak mischievous things
questions.explanation: David describes enemies who actively seek his life through deceit and malicious speech (Psalms 38:12). This reflects the spiritual warfare motif found in Ephesians 6:12 and Jesus' warning about false accusers (John 8:44).

questions.question: How does David describe his own response to the malicious words of his enemies in Psalms 38:13?
options: He hears not and opens not his mouth
questions.correctAnswer: He hears not and opens not his mouth
questions.explanation: David chooses silence in the face of false accusations, likening himself to a deaf and dumb man (Psalms 38:13). This submission echoes Christ's silent suffering before His accusers (Isaiah 53:7, Matthew 27:12-14).

questions.question: According to Psalms 38:15, where does David place his hope?
questions.correctAnswer: In the LORD
questions.explanation: David declares his hope firmly rests in God, affirming trust in divine help despite adversity (Psalms 38:15). This theological theme is central to biblical faith, echoed in Jeremiah 17:7 and Romans 15:13.

questions.question: What does David fear will happen if the LORD does not hear him, according to Psalms 38:16?
options: His enemies will rejoice and magnify themselves
questions.correctAnswer: His enemies will rejoice and magnify themselves
questions.explanation: David fears that without God's intervention, his enemies will triumph and boast over his failure (Psalms 38:16). This reflects the biblical motif of God as defender of the oppressed (Psalm 9:19-20) and Jesus’ promise to vindicate His followers (Luke 18:7-8).

questions.question: What continuous condition does David mention in Psalms 38:17?
options: He is ready to halt and his sorrow is continually before him
questions.correctAnswer: He is ready to halt and his sorrow is continually before him
questions.explanation: David expresses persistent sorrow and physical weakness due to sin's effects (Psalms 38:17). This mirrors the human condition after the Fall (Romans 8:22-23) and David's own acknowledgment of frailty (Psalm 73:26).

questions.question: How does David propose to handle his sin according to Psalms 38:18?
options: He will declare his iniquity and be sorry for his sin
He will hide his sins forever
questions.correctAnswer: He will declare his iniquity and be sorry for his sin
questions.explanation: David chooses confession and repentance, recognizing the need for sorrow over sin (Psalms 38:18). This is consistent with biblical mandates for repentance (1 John 1:9, Proverbs 28:13) and is foundational to salvation theology.

questions.question: What is the nature of David’s enemies as described in Psalms 38:19?
options: They are lively, strong, and multiplied
questions.correctAnswer: They are lively, strong, and multiplied
questions.explanation: David describes his enemies as numerous and vigorous, highlighting the intensity of opposition faced by the righteous (Psalms 38:19). This is echoed in Psalm 27:12 and Jesus’ teaching about enduring persecution (Matthew 5:10).

questions.question: Why does David consider those who render evil for good as adversaries, according to Psalms 38:20?
options: Because he follows what is good
questions.correctAnswer: Because he follows what is good
questions.explanation: David's commitment to righteousness causes opposition by those who repay good with evil (Psalms 38:20). This theme is consistent with Jesus’ teaching in Luke 6:27-28 and the Apostle Paul's experience of persecution (2 Timothy 3:12).

questions.question: What plea does David make to the LORD in Psalms 38:21?
options: Forsake me not and be not far from me
questions.correctAnswer: Forsake me not and be not far from me
questions.explanation: David requests God's nearness and refuses abandonment, reflecting the believer's need for divine presence (Psalms 38:21). This is supported by Deuteronomy 31:6 and Jesus’ promise in Matthew 28:20.

questions.question: What urgent request does David make to the LORD in Psalms 38:22?
options: Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation
questions.explanation: David urgently calls for God's swift help, expressing dependence on divine salvation (Psalms 38:22). This plea aligns with Psalm 70:1 and the New Testament portrayal of Jesus as Savior (Titus 2:13).
